title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. The United States Customs Service is authorized to receive appropriations for salaries, expenses, and equipment to enhance border investigative resources, anticorruption efforts, and combat drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. The authorized amounts are $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and such sums as necessary in each fiscal year thereafter. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is authorized to receive appropriations for salaries, expenses, and equipment to enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border of the United States. The authorized amounts are $113,604,000 for fiscal year 1999 and $121,064,000 for fiscal year 2000. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funds for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, and fixed-site upgrades. Additional funding will be provided in subsequent fiscal years as needed. For the upgrade of truck x-rays to 1-MeV, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, contraband detection kits, ultrasonic container inspection units, and automated targeting systems, a total of $23,750,000 is allocated for fiscal year 1999 by the United States Customs Service. For fiscal year 1999, the United States Customs Service allocated funds for various security systems at ports, including automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, weigh-in-motion sensors, and AM radio systems. The United States Customs Service allocated funds for security systems at ports in fiscal year 1999, including AM radio stations at border crossings, inbound vehicle counters, spotter camera systems, inbound commercial truck transponders, narcotics detectors, and license plate reader automatic systems. In fiscal year 1999, the United States Customs Service allocated funds for security systems at ports, including AM radio stations, inbound vehicle counters, spotter camera systems, narcotics detectors, and license plate reader automatic targeting software for inbound vehicles. Additionally, funds were designated for mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, and other technology along the Southwest land border for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing. In fiscal year 1999, funds were allocated for security systems at ports and border patrol checkpoints, including AM radio stations, surveillance camera systems, spotter cameras, and narcotics detectors. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funds are allocated for the maintenance and support of equipment and training for border patrol checkpoints, including narcotics detectors. The Commissioner of Customs may use funds allocated for equipment maintenance and support for new technologies that are technologically superior and cost-effective compared to existing equipment. The Commissioner of Customs has the authority to reallocate funds for equipment specified in different subparagraphs. The Attorney General has similar authority for specified amounts and equipment. Additionally, there are provisions for peak hours and investigative resource enhancement for the Customs service. The Customs service is authorized to allocate funds for increased staffing and resources at the Southwest and Northern borders to enhance investigative capabilities and reduce waiting times for cargo processing. This includes adding inspectors, special agents, and canine enforcement officers at key locations. The Customs service is authorized to allocate funds for increased staffing and resources at major metropolitan drug or narcotics distribution centers for intensified efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. This includes a net increase of 360 special agents, 40 intelligence analysts, and additional resources. Additionally, there will be a net increase of 50 positions and resources for the Office of Internal Affairs to enhance investigative resources for anticorruption efforts. The costs incurred as a result of the personnel increase will also be covered. In fiscal year 1999 and 2000, funds are allocated for increased staffing at the Southwest and Northern land borders, including additional inspectors, canine enforcement officers, vehicles, and intelligence analysts to enhance investigative resources and reduce waiting times. In fiscal year 1999 and 2000, funds are allocated for increased staffing at the Southwest and Northern land borders, including additional resources for border patrol sectors focusing on drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, an increase in positions for the Office of the Inspector General for anticorruption efforts, and covering costs related to personnel hiring.
